title: 109_hr4014
content: The "Millennium Challenge Reauthorization Act of 2006" establishes the Millennium Challenge Corporation and authorizes assistance through Millennium Challenge Compacts. It includes provisions for congressional notification, annual reporting, and assistance to candidate countries. The Act also outlines the purposes and authorizes appropriations for its implementation. The Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 is amended to focus on reducing poverty through sustainable economic growth, good governance, economic opportunities, and investing in people. Changes are made to the establishment and management of the Millennium Challenge Corporation, including the appointment of the Chief Executive Officer. Authorization of assistance is also addressed. SEC. 4 of the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 is amended to focus on reducing poverty through sustainable economic growth, good governance, economic opportunities, and investing in people. Changes are made to the limitations and assistance provided. The Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 is amended to include an analysis of how beneficiaries will be impacted by each project and the extent to which projects will reduce poverty through economic growth, good governance, and investing in people. The Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 is amended to include consulting with the national legislature of the eligible country and specifying the duration of the Compact, with an exception clause. The Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 is amended to specify project durations in Compacts, with a maximum of 10 years approved by the Board after determining necessity. Congressional notification is required within 15 days of approval. The Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 allows eligible countries and the United States to have up to two Compacts at a time and enter subsequent Compacts after the expiration of existing ones. The United States can enter into a concurrent Compact if the country is making considerable progress in implementing its existing Compact. Subsequent Compacts can be entered into if the country substantially met the objectives of prior Compacts. Effective dates for these amendments apply to Compacts entered into between the United States and a country. The amendments apply to Compacts entered into between the United States and an eligible country under the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003, regardless of the date of enactment. SEC. 6. CONGRESSIONAL AND PUBLIC NOTIFICATION OF COMPACT. Section 610 of the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 is amended to require congressional notification prior to signing a Compact with an eligible country. The Board must provide notification 15 days before signing, including a detailed summary and text of the Compact to the appropriate congressional committees. Section 610 of the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 is amended to require the Chief Executive Officer to publish a detailed summary of the Compact in the Federal Register and on the Corporation's website. The amendments apply to Compacts approved after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 7. ANNUAL REPORT. Amendment to the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 requires reporting on recruitment of minority groups at the Corporation and meeting requirements for small, minority-owned, or disadvantaged business enterprises providing goods and services financed under the Act. The amendment to the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 mandates reporting on contracts with small, minority-owned, or disadvantaged business enterprises financed under specific sections, including the total number and value of contracts. This amendment applies to the report required under section 613 of the Act. The Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 requires reporting on contracts with small, minority-owned, or disadvantaged business enterprises for fiscal year 2007 and beyond. SEC. 8 of the Millennium Challenge Act of 2003 is amended to ensure the participation of U.S. small, minority-owned, and disadvantaged businesses in providing goods and services financed with funds under specific sections. This amendment applies to funds for fiscal year 2007 and beyond. SEC. 9. Assistance to certain candidate countries is amended for a fiscal year. SEC. 10. Authorization of appropriations amended for fiscal years 2007 through 2009.
